myth_text:
SOME FISHERMEN were out trawling their nets. Perceiving them to be very
      heavy, they danced about for joy and supposed that they had taken a large
      catch. When they had dragged the nets to the shore they found but few
      fish: the nets were full of sand and stones, and the men were beyond
      measure cast down so much at the disappointment which had befallen them,
      but because they had formed such very different expectations. One of their
      company, an old man, said, "Let us cease lamenting, my mates, for, as it
      seems to me, sorrow is always the twin sister of joy; and it was only to
      be looked for that we, who just now were over-rejoiced, should next have
      something to make us sad."
